I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  A delegation from the Australian Agency for International Development (AusAID) visited the 
South Asia Department (SARD) at the headquarters of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) on 6–7 
February 2006 to discuss and identify areas for more intensive operational partnerships in South Asia, 
particularly the establishment of a grant financing facility.1  AusAID and SARD noted that although 
South Asia is attracting international attention because of its robust economic performance, it faces 
significant development challenges, and identified five key areas for cooperation: (i) governance; (ii) 
promotion  of  inclusive  growth;  (iii)  challenges  associated  with  rapid  urbanization  and  the  rise  of 
megacities; (iv) human resource development, particularly improved delivery of social services (e.g., 
education, health, water and sanitation); and (v) regional cooperation and integration. This proposed 
technical  assistance  (TA)  has  been  prepared  to  address  these  challenges  and  the  design  and 
monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.2 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  The global community views South Asia as the next rapid growth area after East Asia. The 
human development realities in the region are sobering, however. For example, South Asia has the 
most people living below the US$1 per day poverty line, the largest proportion of illiterate people, the 
most out-of-school children, and the most children dying before reaching the age of 5. 
 
3.  AusAID and ADB see the following significant development challenges emerging in South Asia. 
 
(i)  There is a growing need to institute measures to ensure enhancement of governance. In 
particular, there is a need to build (a) more effective mechanisms  for delivery of social 
services  to  end  users  (e.g.  through  devolution),  and  more  streamlined  public 
administration systems to facilitate development of such mechanisms; and (b) sound 
foundations of good governance in institutions addressing public resource management, 
gender mainstreaming, judicial administration, and anticorruption.  
 
(ii)  It is necessary to take steps to ensure inclusive growth in South Asia. Future economic 
growth  and  employment  opportunities  will  demand  skills  that  school  dropouts  lack, 
effectively  reducing  employment  opportunities  for  the  illiterate  poor.  In  addition, 
economic growth in South Asia has not necessarily led to substantial improvements in 
the quality of life of the poor.  
 
(iii)  South Asia is experiencing rapid urbanization and the rise of megacities, bringing both 
immense opportunities in relation to ongoing globalization, but also challenges. By 2015, 
five of the world’s 13 megacities will be located in South Asia. These megacities can 
spur economic growth, but also pose challenges, including the “urbanization of poverty” 
phenomenon.  The  importance  of  appropriate  urban  management—which  secures 
infrastructure financing, effectively delivers services, and promotes responsible urban 
development (e.g. secondary towns and cities)  and participatory local governance—will 
increase in the future. 
 
(iv)  Even  as  South  Asia  searches  for  appropriate  approaches  to  the  management  of  
megacities, balanced and sustainable development requires significant increases in the 
                                                 
1    The Australia-ADB South Asia Development Partnership Facility (AASADPF) which will  finance innovative development 
services that address some major challenges faced by developing member countries (DMCs) in South Asia, comprising  
Afghanistan, Bangladesh, Bhutan, India, Maldives, Nepal, Pakistan, and Sri Lanka. Although the realignment of the 
regional departments effective 1 May 2006 has transferred Afghanistan and Pakistan from SARD to the Central and West  
Asia Department (CWRD), AusAID has agreed to continue to include Afghanistan and Pakistan under AASADPF. Thus, in 
this paper, South Asia covers all eight DMCs mentioned above. ADB’s Board of Directors approved the establishment of 
the AASADPF on 7 June 2006. The AASADPF will be supported by A$11 million (about US$8.5 million equivalent at the 
current exchange rate) from the Government of Australia (the Government) over the next 5 years. 
2    The concept paper on the TA was approved by ADB Management on 15 May 2006. The TA first appeared in ADB 
Business Opportunities on 19 May 2006.

2   
provision  and  effectiveness  of  public  and  private  social  services,  in  areas  such  as 
education, health, and water supply and sanitation. Significant improvements in human 
resources are required to deliver the needed high quality and timely social services. 
 
(v)  The Islamabad Declaration developed during the 12th Summit (January 2004) of the 
South  Asian  Association  for  Regional  Cooperation  (SAARC)  pledged  to  intensify 
cooperation  and  eradicate  poverty  in  South  Asia,  and  to  resolve  any  conflict  and 
disputes through peaceful means. During the 13th SAARC Summit, held in Dhaka in 
November 2005, the heads of state or government of the SAARC member countries (the 
SAARC leaders) stressed that accelerating cooperation in core economic areas was of 
vital importance to making South Asia truly vibrant, dynamic, and secure.3 South Asia’s 
interest in developing closer cooperation with regional groupings in Southeast Asia, the 
Greater Mekong Subregion (GMS), and the Association of Southeast Asian Nations 
(ASEAN)  is  also  increasing.  Countries  in  South  and  Southeast  Asia  have  started 
interregional  cooperation  initiatives,  such  as  the  Bay  of  Bengal  Initiative  for  Multi-
Sectoral Technical and Economic Cooperation (BIMSTEC).  
 
 
4.  Efforts to enhance the quality of and access to basic services must focus on the institutions 
responsible for delivery of basic services, in addition to more commonly emphasized sector-specific 
issues.    Many  institutional  issues  are  multisectoral,  involving  complex  governance  and  financing 
considerations. The core issue—underlying the need for institutional reform, and for enhanced basic 
service delivery mechanisms—is ensuring enhanced governance in the countries of the region.4 As the 
pace of economic globalization has increased, economic interdependence among countries in South 
Asia has progressively deepened. South Asia has recently achieved remarkable economic growth, 
leading to intensification of linkages with international and regional markets. Further strengthening of 
regional  cooperation  and  integration  has  become  essential  to  maintaining  economic  growth  and 
reducing poverty. The region’s countries face many common challenges, and both AusAID and ADB 
are increasing their operational emphasis on South Asia;  consequently, a regional approach covering 
South Asia is considered appropriate for the proposed technical assistance (TA). The TA is in line with 
ADB’s overall vision for Asia and the Pacific, the Medium-Term Strategy II (2006-2008), regional 
cooperation strategy and programs, and country strategy and programs for DMCs in South Asia. 
 
III.  THE PROPOSED TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
5.  The  intended  overall  impact  of  the  proposed  regional  TA—the  Development  Partnership 
Program for South Asia (DPPSA)—is sustained progress made by participating DMCs in South Asia 
toward attaining the Millennium Development Goals (MDGs).5 The envisaged outcome under the 
DPPSA is innovative approaches to addressing key development challenges in South Asia, which will 
be  implemented,  evaluated,  documented,  and  disseminated  within  the  region  and  to  other  Asian 
countries.6 DPPSA outputs comprise (i) development and implementation of innovative programs that 
will address key development challenges; (ii) targeted assessments aimed at enhancing the analytical 
                                                 
3    At the Summit, the SAARC leaders agreed to invite Afghanistan to join as SAARC’s eighth member. 
4    Enhanced governance implies a greater focus on accountability of service providers, transparency in the provision of 
services, and end users’ participation in the design and delivery of such services. Participation by end users throughout 
the process increases the likelihood of positive impacts on the population. 
5     The MDGs comprise eight goals: (i) eradicate extreme poverty and hunger; (ii) achieve universal primary education; (iii) 
promote gender equality and empower women; (iv) reduce child mortality; (v) improve maternal health; (vi) combat 
HIV/AIDS, malaria, and other diseases; (vii) ensure environmental sustainability; and (viii) develop a global partnership for 
development. 
6    In  keeping  with  the  ongoing  Innovation  and  Efficiency  Initiative,  additional  benefits  of  the  proposed  TA  include:  
(i) improvements in operational efficiency in providing high quality development assistance services to DMCs in South 
Asia, by increasing the quality of ADB services to address the development challenges selected for DPPSA, rather than 
on associated paper preparation; and (ii) reduction in the number of TA papers prepared during the next 5 years.

3
basis  for  policy  dialogue  and  raising  awareness  on,  and  building  capacity  for,  key  development 
challenges;  (iii)  regional  cooperation  and  integration  activities;  and  (iv)  information  dissemination 
activities that will identify, compile, and disseminate good practices and lessons learned for addressing 
the major challenges facing South Asia. These outputs will support the impact and outcome of the 
proposed TA. 
B.   Methodology and Key Activities 
6.  Eligibility. Countries eligible for financing under the proposed regional TA are Afghanistan, 
Bangladesh, Bhutan, India, Maldives, Nepal, Pakistan, and Sri Lanka.7 Projects and programs must 
address one or more of five prioritized areas: (i) enhanced governance, particularly at the local level, 
where service delivery interfaces with end users, and including an emphasis on decentralization and 
devolution  in  countries  of  the  region;  (ii)  urban  infrastructure  and  service  delivery,  including  in 
megacities and secondary cities and towns, and associated issues such as municipal financing for 
much needed infrastructure and participatory local governance;8 (iii) inclusive growth, so that gains 
from economic development are shared by as wide a population base as possible; (iv) human resource 
development,  particularly  in  targeting  improved  service delivery  in  education,  health,  9  water  and 
sanitation, and other social services; and (v) regional cooperation and integration.10 DPPSA financing 
will primarily focus on innovative interventions through technical assistance operations, while targeted 
assessments, regional cooperation and integration activities, and information dissemination activities 
will also be conducted.11 The total financing requirement from DPPSA for each proposed project or 
program should normally not exceed US$500,000,12 and they should focus on one or more of DPPSA’s 
five key eligible areas. Each project or program will take the form of an innovative intervention, a 
targeted assessment, a regional cooperation and integration activity, or an information dissemination 
activity. Proposed projects or programs should be in addition to, and not substitute for, ADB’s ongoing 
or programmed activities.  
 
7.  Selection Procedures. Proposals will be reviewed and recommendations for funding will be 
made on the basis of the selection criteria specified in Appendix 2.  
 
8.  Output  1:  Innovative  Interventions.  The  proposed  TA  will  support  innovative  ideas  that 
demonstrate unique institutional arrangements, participatory approaches, or technical solutions that fit 
the  domestic  situation  in  participating  DMCs,  while  clearly  identifying  the  potential  for  successful 
                                                 
7    AusAID and ADB have agreed that support to Afghanistan under the proposed TA will focus solely on regional integration 
and cooperation, because the operation area of the AusAID counterpart office—North and South Asia Section—does not 
include Afghanistan. In addition, AusAID is phasing out its development cooperation with India as a result of the 
Government of India’s decision in 2003 to limit its development engagement to a reduced number of bilateral aid donors. 
AusAID and ADB have thus agreed that support to India under the proposed TA will focus primarily on integration and 
cooperation activities.   
8    Including knowledge generation and dissemination protocols that enable local experiences to be fed back into national 
policy-making processes. 
9   AusAID and ADB have agreed not to finance the following family planning activities without the prior written consent of the 
Government of Australia: (i) family planning services, including counseling; (ii) training in the practice of family planning; 
(iii) distributing contraceptives for family planning purposes; (iv) developing and distributing family planning information, 
education, and communication materials; and (v) capacity building for organizations that deliver family planning. Other 
activities, which target diseases such as HIV/AIDS, and avian influenza and other emerging diseases, may be financed by 
the Government over and above A$11 million, through a separate agreement between AusAID and ADB.  
10   Regional cooperation and integration activities will include those undertaken by SARD and CWRD, and also the work of 
ADB’s Office of Regional Economic Integration (OREI); the latter proposals should have South Asia as a primary focus in 
order to access financing from the proposed TA.  
11   Where viability and sustainability are ensured, components of investment projects and stand-alone grant-financed work 
may also be considered for financing. 
12   This threshold amount is proposed based on assessments of the average project size financed under existing trust funds 
provided by the Governments of Japan, United Kingdom, and the Netherlands. Under special cases, with advisory panel 
approval, proposals greater than US$500,000 may be considered.

replication, mainstreaming, and/or upscaling in one or more countries. Public–private partnership (PPP) 
opportunities and working with nongovernment organizations (NGOs) will be encouraged. 
 
9.  Output 2: Targeted Assessments. This component will include activities aimed at enhancing 
the analytical basis for policy dialogue and raising awareness on, and building capacity for, addressing 
key development challenges faced by South Asia. Activities include focused studies; action research; 
and targeted activities aimed at removing regulatory, policy-related, institutional, organizational, social, 
technical, and financial barriers to improved basic service delivery at the local level, including identifying 
opportunities  for  PPP  and  working  with  NGOs.  Assessments  will  have  strong  linkages  to  ADB 
operations for implementation of the findings, will answer some of the key development challenges13 
faced by South Asia, and will be an important discussion base for policy dialogue.   
10.  Output 3: Regional Cooperation and Integration. This component will include activities to 
enhance regional cooperation and integration among DMCs in South Asia and support their efforts to 
cooperate and integrate with other economies within and outside Asia. Activities will include, among 
others, strategically important regional conferences, workshops, and assessments. 
11.  Output 4: Information Dissemination. This component will identify, compile, and disseminate 
good practices and lessons learned for addressing development issues covered by the proposed TA. 
The  component  will  include  awareness  campaigns,  capacity-building  activities,  conferences  and 
workshops, publication of lessons learned, and integration of the knowledge gained into the information 
dissemination and the knowledge management activities of the Regional and Sustainable Development 
Department  (RSDD).  As  part  of  ADB’s  information  dissemination  effort,  a  communication  and 
information  dissemination  plan  will  be  developed  to  identify  effective  dissemination  methods  and 
venues, including internet and intranet-based information management.   
C.   Cost and Financing 
12.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at A$11 million (about US$8.5 million equivalent at the 
current exchange rate). The proposed TA will be financed on a grant basis by the AASADPF, funded by 
the Government of Australia.14 The cost estimates include consulting services, equipment, materials, 
conferences, workshops, information dissemination activities including publications, and administrative 
costs.15 The cost estimates and financing plan are provided in Appendix 3. 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
13.  ADB will be the executing agency for the proposed TA, which will be implemented over 6 years, 
starting from the approval date of the proposed TA.16 
14.  Proposals will be actively solicited and reviewed periodically. The Country Coordination and 
Regional Cooperation Division (SAOC) of SARD will administer the proposed TA in close coordination 
with relevant sector divisions of SARD and Central and West Asia Department (CWRD), technical 
experts from RSDD, and other offices17 relevant to the proposed TA operations. 
 
15.  The directors of relevant divisions of SARD and CWRD as well as country directors of the 
resident missions in South Asia will send proposals to a secretariat to be established for the AASADPF 
                                                 
13   One particular challenge is the relationship between improved basic service delivery and the impact on poor people’s 
livelihood, health, and vulnerability. 
14  On 19 April 2006, AusAID approved its contribution to AASADPF totaling A$11 million over the next 5 years. 
15   Civil works may also be financed. 
16   Implementation over 6 years from the date of approval of the proposed regional TA is recommended, to give sufficient 
time for implementation of projects or programs approved in the 5th year of AASADPF operations; proposals will be 
approved during the AASADPF 5-year operational period. Assistance to each participating DMC will not begin until ADB 
receives a confirmation of no objection from the participating DMC government. 
17   Relevant offices include the Office of the General Counsel (OGC), Controller’s Department, Central Operations Services 
Office (COSO), Department of External Relations, Office of Cofinancing Operations (OCO) and Office of Regional 
Economic Integration (OREI).

5
(AASADPF secretariat).18 Proposals need to meet the eligibility criteria, including ensuring consistency 
between the proposals and ADB’s regional cooperation strategy and programs and country strategy 
and programs for the eligible countries, and road maps relevant to the proposed TA.19 The AASADPF 
secretariat will undertake initial proposal reviews20 and make recommendations to a DPPSA advisory 
panel. 
16.  The  DPPSA  advisory  panel  will  be  headed  by  the  director  of  SAOC  and  will  comprise 
representatives of SARD, CWRD, and RSDD. It will have overall program oversight responsibilities, 
including  reviewing  and  approving  proposals  and  overseeing  progress  in  implementing  approved 
projects. Proposals will be reviewed, prioritized based on the eligibility and selection criteria (Appendix 
2), and selected for funding. Resident missions and relevant sector divisions of SARD and CWRD are 
responsible  for  ensuring  consistency  in  the  proposals,  supervising  implementation  progress,  and 
periodically reporting progress to the AASADPF secretariat.   
17.  The AASADPF secretariat will be responsible for the day-to-day management of DPPSA and 
AASADPF, including the use of AASADPF funds. The AASADPF secretariat will regularly collaborate 
with relevant departments and offices to eliminate any duplication and/or conflict with other similar fund 
operations or research activities promoted by ADB.21 The AASADPF secretariat will work with ADB’s 
Department of External Relations to develop and implement an information dissemination plan to 
identify effective dissemination venues and methods, and collaborate with similar initiatives conducted 
by ADB’s development partners, including NGOs, to enhance synergy, co-host workshops, and explore 
future collaboration for TA implementation.   
 
18.  ADB will recruit consultants in accordance with the Guidelines on the Use of Consultants. Their 
tasks will include evaluating and preparing a completion report for each approved TA activity. Civil 
works, equipment, and materials to be financed by the TA will be procured in accordance with ADB’s 
Procurement Guidelines.   
 
19.  Progress reports on the proposed TA and use of the AASADPF will be prepared annually by the 
AASADPF secretariat in collaboration with the Controller’s Department and the Office of Cofinancing 
Operations. TA activities will be monitored and reports made available through the TA website. 
   
IV. THE PRESIDENT'S RECOMMENDATION 
20.  The President recommends that the Board approve ADB administering technical assistance not 
exceeding A$11 million (about US$8.5 million equivalent) to be financed on a grant basis by the 
Australia-ADB South Asia Development Partnership Facility for the Development Partnership Program 
for South Asia. 
                                                 
18   The AASADPF secretariat will comprise representatives of SARD and CWRD and a consultant. The secretariat will not 
passively receive proposals, but  will work with participating DMCs, through sector staff members and resident missions, 
to develop specific proposals that fit the criteria, while maintaining the overall balance of activities financed under DPPSA. 
19    Criteria also include confirmation of (i) approvals by participating DMC governments of the proposed projects or programs, 
and (ii) budgetary appropriations to such projects and programs. 
20   Due diligence in the fields of consulting services and procurement, legal aspects, and environment and social matters will 
also be conducted by COSO, OGC, and RSDD. 
21    The close coordination required includes (i) OCO-managed funds such as the Japan Special Fund and Japan Fund for 
Poverty Reduction; (ii) RSDD-managed funds such as the (a) Poverty Reduction Cooperation Fund, (b) Governance 
Cooperation Fund, (c) Cooperation Fund for the Water Sector, (d) Poverty and Environment Fund, (e) Gender and 
Development Fund, (f) PRC Regional Cooperation and Poverty Reduction Fund; and (iii) other similar funds and research 
initiatives supported by ADB through regional departments and OCO.

DEVELOPMENT PARTNERSHIP PROGRAM FOR SOUTH ASIA 
 ELIGIBILITY AND SELECTION CRITERIA 
 
1.  To be eligible for funding, each proposal 
 
(i)  must be approved during the Australia-ADB South Asia Development Partnership 
Facility (AASADPF) period;1 
(ii)  must be implemented within the participating developing member countries (DMCs) 
during the proposed regional technical assistance (TA) period;2 
(iii)  must focus on interventions in one or more of the five prioritized areas identified for 
the Development Partnership Program for South Asia (DPPSA) and be in keeping 
with ADB’s overall vision for Asia and the Pacific, the Medium-Term Strategy II 
(2006-2008), regional cooperation strategy and programs, and country strategy and 
programs for eligible countries and road maps relevant to the proposed TA;3 
(iv)  must be in addition to, and not substitute for, ongoing or programmed activities;  
(v)  should normally not cost more than US$500,000;4 and 
(vi)  must  have  clear  objectives,  performance  indicators,  monitoring  mechanisms,  a 
realistic budget, and appropriate cost control systems for managing expenditures. 
 
2.  DMCs  eligible  for  financing  under  the  proposed  TA  are  Afghanistan,  Bangladesh, 
Bhutan, India, Maldives, Nepal, Pakistan, and Sri Lanka.5 
 
3.  Eligible activities are those focusing on (i) enhanced governance, particularly at the local 
level,  where  service  delivery  interfaces  with  end  users,  and  including  an  emphasis  on 
decentralization and devolution in countries of the region; (ii) urban infrastructure and service 
delivery, including in megacities and secondary cities and towns, and associated issues such as 
municipal financing for much needed infrastructure and participatory local level governance;6 
(iii) inclusive growth, so that the gains from economic development are shared by as wide a 
population  base  as  possible;  (iv)  human  resource  development,  particularly  in  targeting 
improved service delivery in education, health,7 water and sanitation, and other such social 
services; and (v) regional cooperation and integration.8

2   Six years from the approval of the proposed regional TA to give sufficient time for the implementation of projects 
or programs approved in the 5th year of the AASADPF operations. Extension may be considered if AusAID and 
ADB agree to such a necessity. 
3     Including confirmation of approvals by participating DMC governments of the proposed projects or programs and 
budgetary appropriations to such projects and programs. 
4    Under special cases, with advisory panel approval, proposals greater than US$500,000 may be considered.  
5   Although the realignment of the regional departments effective 1 May 2006 has transferred Afghanistan and 
Pakistan from South Asia Department (SARD) to Central and West  Asia Department (CWRD), AusAID has 
agreed to continue to include Afghanistan and Pakistan. Thus, in this paper, South Asia covers all eight DMCs 
mentioned above. AusAID and ADB have agreed that support to Afghanistan under the proposed TA will focus 
solely on regional integration and cooperation, because the operation area of the AusAID counterpart office—
North and South Asia Section—does not include Afghanistan. In addition, AusAID is phasing out its development 
cooperation with India as a result of the Government of India’s decision in 2003 to limit its development 
engagement to a reduced number of bilateral aid donors. AusAID and ADB have thus agreed that support to 
India under the proposed TA will focus primarily on regional integration and cooperation activities. 
6   Including knowledge generation and dissemination protocols that enable local experiences to be fed back into 
national policy-making processes. 
7    AusAID and ADB have agreed not to finance the following family planning activities without the prior written 
consent of the Government of Australia: (i) family planning services, including counseling; (ii) training in the 
practice of family planning; (iii) distributing contraceptives for family planning purposes; (iv) developing and

Projects will be selected on a competitive basis within the participating DMCs. The TA will not 
normally fund activities if they wholly comprise activities that would typically be included in 
preparatory TA or loan-funded projects. Proposals will be screened through two due diligence 
groups: (i) a secretariat to be established for AASADPF (AASADPF secretariat), and (ii) an 
advisory panel to be established for DPPSA. 
4.  Recommendations for funding will be made on the basis of the following criteria:  
 
(i)  Output 1–Innovative Interventions9 
 
(a)  Proposed projects will include sound financing plans for continuation of 
activities  and/or  will  have  activities  whose  benefits  are  sustainable 
beyond the TA program periods. 
(b)  Proposed projects will be prepared and implemented using participatory 
approaches, with strong collaboration among stakeholders10 to enhance 
ownership and commitment to actions. 
(c)  Proposed projects will be consistent with ADB’s Policy on Gender and 
Development  and  safeguard  policies, 11   and  policies  relating  to 
anticorruption  and  counterterrorism,12  and  will  give  due  attention  to 
women, indigenous peoples, and other vulnerable groups. 
(d)  Proposed projects will contain new and/or innovative approaches and 
mechanisms  (such  as  institutional  arrangements,  partnerships, 
participation,  or  technological  solutions)  including  public–private 
partnership  (PPP)  opportunities  and  working  with  nongovernment 
organizations (NGOs). 
(e)  Proposed  projects  will  have  the  potential  to  be  upscaled  (by  taking 
measures such as increasing the number of beneficiaries, or the benefits 
provided through improved basic service delivery) or replicated in ADB-
financed projects. 
(f)  Proposed projects will be fully consistent with, and in support of, national 
poverty reduction strategies, and ADB’s country and regional cooperation 
strategies and programs. 
                                                                                                                                                          
distributing family planning information, education, and communication materials; and (v) capacity building for 
organizations that deliver family planning. Other activities, which target diseases such as HIV/AIDS, and avian 
influenza and other emerging diseases, may be financed by the Government over and above A$11 million 
through a separate agreement between AusAID and ADB. 
8   Regional cooperation and integration activities will include the activities of SARD and CWRD and the work of the 
Office of Regional Economic Integration (OREI) at ADB.  
9    Examples of ADB’s innovative work in governance and social service delivery include, among others, (i) support 
to  devolved  social  services  program  in  Pakistan,  (ii)  anticorruption  efforts  in  Bangladesh,  (iii)  a  fiscal 
management reform program in Sri Lanka, (iv) an administration of justice project in India, (v) a Punjab resource 
management program in Pakistan, and (vi) mega city development in Karachi, Pakistan. 
10    Stakeholders include local communities, civil society (including nongovernment organizations), private sector,

(ii)  Output 2 –Targeted Assessments 
 
(a)  Proposed  assessments  will  aim  at  enhancing  the  analytical  basis  for 
policy  dialogue  and  raising  awareness  on,  and  building  capacity  for 
addressing, the five key development challenges selected for DPPSA. 
(b)  Proposed assessments will aim at removing problem-specific regulatory, 
policy-related, institutional, organizational, social, technical, and financial 
barriers  to  improving  environmental  management  at  the  local  level, 
including PPP opportunities and working with NGOs. 
(c)  Proposed assessments will have strong linkages to ADB operations so 
that the findings of the assessments will be implemented. 
(d)  Priority will be given to the relationships between improved basic service 
delivery and its impact on the livelihoods, health, and vulnerability of the 
poor. 
 
(iii)  Output 3–Regional Cooperation and Integration13 
 
(a)  Proposed  activities  will  include  enhancing  regional  cooperation  and 
integration among DMCs in South Asia and supporting their efforts to 
cooperate and integrate with other parts of the economies within and 
outside Asia. 
(b)  Proposed  activities  will  include,  among  others,  strategically  important 
regional  conferences,  workshops,  and  assessments  on  regional 
 
cooperation and integration.
 
(iv)  Output 4–Information Dissemination Activities 
 
(a)  Proposed activities will focus on the development challenges and eligible 
activities identified for DPPSA. 
(b)  Proposed activities will focus on good practices and lessons learned in 
conjunction with DPPSA activities. 
(c)  Proposed activities will aim at replication of best practices and lessons 
learned in conjunction with DPPSA activities for practical application in 
participating DMCs and other DMCs in Asia. 
(d)  Priority will be given to activities that improve basic service delivery and 
positively impact the livelihoods, health, and vulnerability of the poor.  
(e)  Priority will also given to activities that encourage PPP opportunities and 
working with NGOs. 
 
                                                 
13    An example of ADB’s innovative work in regional cooperation and integration is a study on economic cooperation 
between East Asia and South Asia being conducted by OREI. Other innovative regional cooperation and 
integration activities will be actively pursued.
